title: FCO could lift Tunisia advice for winter
text:
FCO could lift Tunisia advice for winter 21 July 2015 Save 
Foreign Office (FCO) advice against all but essential travel to Tunisia could be lifted in time for the winter season. 
The Telegraph reports that foreign secretary Philip Hammond met with Tunisian prime minister Habid Essid yesterday at a meeting to discuss how the EU can help the struggling country. 
He told him the current FCO ban against all but essential travel to the country could be lifted within “weeks, certainly months” providing the country can show it is making progress in hunting down the terrorist network responsible for the massacre of 38 tourists in Sousse last month. 
He also urged the country to tighten security in the country where tourists have now been targeted twice by terrorists since the start of the year. 
Hammond said: “There is quite a big gain for Tunisia potentially if it can get this right. 
“What I have said to the Tunisian PM is we need to see some progress on the ground – I’m not suggesting in any way they are dragging their heels, they are doing a thorough investigation – but we need to see some progress in exposing the full extent of this network behind these attacks. 
“We’d like nothing better than to be able to give a green light for tourism, but we can only do that when we are confident that it is safe.”Phillip Hammond 
“And we need to see some progress on reassurance measures, more checkpoints, more static guarding, more entrance controls to hotels, and they have got all that on board and they are telling us they are committed to doing it. 
“We’d like nothing better than to be able to give a green light for tourism, but we can only do that when we are confident that it is safe. 
“If they had some good luck on the investigation, and were prepared to take the measures necessary to provide security assurance, I think it could even be weeks, certainly months. 
“The problem is tour operators, having cancelled their season, are not likely to go back this year. Whether it is weeks or months, we are talking about Tunisia’s re-emergence into the market for probably the winter season.”
